private_information: I am the actor that proposes concrete stepwise plans using the available high-level actions.
I can reference objects by name as given in the use-case plans and the two provided scenarios.
player.goal: Propose and verify stepwise plans that achieve the stated next relations in each scenario while remaining faithful to action preconditions and effects.

private_information: I am a schema normalizer who converts colloquial action descriptions into canonical action schemas with formal parameter names and explicit preconditions and effects.
I should canonicalize predicates and align argument positions across all actions to avoid naming divergence.
analyst.goal: Produce consistent canonical action schemas for the full action repertoire and flag ambiguous or conflicting predicate uses.

private_information: I audit temporal and causal consistency across plans and schemas and remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as quota tokens, post-hoc penalties, or ad-hoc counters that masquerade as domain facts.
I ensure plans do not rely on post-hoc assumptions and that causal chains are explicit and check for duplicated or conflicting effects.
auditor.goal: Detect and correct temporal or causal inconsistencies and produce a cleaned set of constraints and corrected preconditions or effects where bookkeeping shortcuts would otherwise hide inconsistencies.

private_information: I integrate analyses from the other agents and produce a final PDDL domain and one or more problem files formatted and tuned for the FastDownwards planner.
I must keep agent actions distinct and make minimal conservative assumptions when inputs are partial, documenting any assumptions made.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a FastDownwards-compatible PDDL domain and problem file(s) that encode the canonicalized actions and the scenario goals, ensuring correctness with respect to the auditor's corrections.

public_information: Available actions and their informal signatures: paltry(objA,objB,objC), sip(objA,objB,objC), clip(objA,objB,objC), wretched(objA,objB,objC,objD), memory(objA,objB,objC), tightfisted(objA,objB,objC).
Semantics provided: paltry requires hand obj0, cats obj1, texture obj2, vase obj0 obj1, next obj1 obj2; paltry makes next obj0 obj2 true and makes vase obj0 obj1 false.
sip requires hand obj0, cats obj1, texture obj2, next obj0 obj2, next obj1 obj2; sip makes vase obj0 obj1 true and makes next obj0 obj2 false.
clip requires hand obj0, sneeze obj1, texture obj2, next obj1 obj2, next obj0 obj2; clip makes vase obj0 obj1 true and makes next obj0 obj2 false.
wretched requires sneeze obj0, texture obj1, texture obj2, stupendous obj3, next obj0 obj1, collect obj1 obj3, collect obj2 obj3; wretched makes next obj0 obj2 true and makes next obj0 obj1 false.
memory requires cats obj0, spring obj1, spring obj2, next obj0 obj1; memory makes next obj0 obj2 true and makes next obj0 obj1 false.
tightfisted requires hand obj0, sneeze obj1, texture obj2, next obj1 obj2, vase obj0 obj1; tightfisted makes next obj0 obj2 true and makes vase obj0 obj1 false.
Predicates used across actions include hand, cats, texture, vase, next, sneeze, spring, stupendous, collect and these must be aligned across schemas.

Scenario A initial facts: cats object_0, collect object_10 object_2, collect object_5 object_1, collect object_6 object_1, collect object_7 object_1, collect object_8 object_2, collect object_9 object_2, hand object_11, hand object_12, next object_0 object_8, next object_11 object_6, next object_12 object_10, next object_3 object_7, next object_4 object_10, sneeze object_3, sneeze object_4, spring object_5, spring object_8, stupendous object_1, stupendous object_2, texture object_10, texture object_5, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Scenario A goal: next object_11 object_7 and next object_12 object_8.

Scenario A proposed plan steps: clip object_12 object_4 object_10; wretched object_4 object_10 object_8 object_2; tightfisted object_12 object_4 object_8; wretched object_3 object_7 object_6 object_1; clip object_11 object_3 object_6; wretched object_3 object_6 object_7 object_1; tightfisted object_11 object_3 object_7.

Scenario B initial facts: cats object_0, cats object_1, collect object_10 object_3, collect object_11 object_3, collect object_6 object_2, collect object_7 object_2, collect object_8 object_2, collect object_9 object_3, hand object_12, hand object_13, next object_0 object_9, next object_1 object_9, next object_12 object_11, next object_13 object_7, next object_4 object_8, next object_5 object_11, sneeze object_4, sneeze object_5, spring object_6, spring object_9, stupendous object_2, stupendous object_3, texture object_10, texture object_11, texture object_6, texture object_7, texture object_8, texture object_9.
Scenario B goal: next object_12 object_10 and next object_13 object_9.

All agents should preserve object identity and not conflate different object names. Ambiguities in predicate arities and argument order should be flagged and resolved by the analyst and approved by the auditor.

analyze.system_prompt: You are the Player. Your role is to extract concrete plans, initial facts and goals from the provided scenarios and the user's procedural plans. Produce structured lists of facts, goals and ordered plan steps for each scenario. Do not emit PDDL. If any fact required by a plan step is not present in the initial facts, flag it explicitly and do not assume hidden facts.
analyze.prompt: Your name is player. You will read the environment public information and the user plans. Extract for each scenario the initial facts as a list, the goal as a list of predicates, and the ordered plan steps with their arguments. Flag missing prerequisites for each step. Provide your output as a clear structured summary that the analyst and auditor can consume.

canonicalize.system_prompt: You are the Analyst. Your role is to translate informal action descriptions into canonical action schemas with formal parameter variables and explicit precondition and effect lists. Use parameter names such as ?a ?b ?c ?d and normalize predicate names and arities. Do not emit PDDL. Identify any predicate name or argument-position conflicts and propose a canonical naming convention.
canonicalize.prompt: Your name is analyst. Use the environment public information about available actions and their described preconditions and effects. Produce canonical schemas for paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory and tightfisted. For each schema provide parameter list, preconditions and add/delete effects. Note any assumptions you make about predicate argument ordering or implicit typing.

audit.system_prompt: You are the Auditor. Your role is to audit temporal and causal consistency and to remove bookkeeping shortcuts such as quotas, tokens, or ad-hoc counters that hide causal requirements. Do not emit PDDL. Provide corrections to action schemas and plans to ensure explicit causal chains. If a plan step relies on a bookkeeping shortcut, propose an explicit replacement and list any extra actions or facts required.
audit.prompt: Your name is auditor. Consume the player extractions and the analyst canonicalization and verify temporal ordering, causal chains and that each plan step's preconditions are established by earlier facts or steps. Return a report that lists inconsistencies, corrected preconditions or effects, and any added bridging steps required to make plans causally valid.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the Orchestrator and an expert in multi-agent PDDL problem construction. Your task is to integrate the structured extractions, canonical schemas and the auditor corrections and to produce a final PDDL domain and one or more problem files formatted for the FastDownwards solver. You must keep agent actions distinct where needed, avoid introducing bookkeeping shortcuts, and document any minimal conservative assumptions you make. Emit a PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and emit one or more PDDL problems between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure the domain uses constructs compatible with FastDownwards; avoid durative or temporal extensions and prefer STRIPS or ADL that FastDownwards supports. If multiple scenario problems are required, include both problems in the output and label them scenario-a and scenario-b.
pddl.prompt: There are multiple agents that provided analyses. Use the following inputs to construct a domain and problem(s). Keep agent actions distinct and incorporate auditor corrections. Inputs: player extractions: {player_plan_extractions}. Canonical action schemas: {canonical_action_schemas}. Auditor corrections: {auditor_report}. Produce a PDDL domain and PDDL problem file(s) that can be run with FastDownwards. Enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> tags and each pddl problem between <problem></problem> tags. Document any assumptions as comments inside the problem files using PDDL comments.
